p: Based on the in-vitro assays of all fractions of Eryngium caeruleum, the chloroform fraction was selected for the in-vivo assay as can be seen in Table 3. In acute toxicity studies, the Ec.Chf was found to be safe, causing no mortality or unwanted reactions. The chloroform fraction of Eryngium caeruleum was observed to be a potent antidiabetic agent following the in-vivo experiments. The Ec.Chf at concentrations of 500, 250, 125, 62.5, and 31.25 μg/kg body weight exhibited a blood glucose level of 10.3, 15.4, 16.8, 17.8, and 19.4 mmol/liter in mice. Obviously, the blood glucose level at 24 h and 500 μg/kg was 10.3 mmol/liter which was almost in comparison to the standard drug value which was 7.9 mmol/liter.
